Thanks a ton for teaching this class, Jake. Really appreciate you and the rest of our class. I wish you guys all the best of luck in the future!
Thanks for a fantastic class, Jake! Your explanations were amazing--precise, clear, attuned to beginners. So I think you've got that teaching thing in the bag :smiley:.

<@U1VAKEUHJ> Thank you so much for taking the time to teach the JavaScript fundamentals course I had a wonderful time and had a lot of breakthroughs thanks to your help. You are definitely in the top ten of my list for best teachers/mentors along with <@U38KEPD62>. Again thank you so much and wish you good luck on your future endeavors my friend. Also those wishes of good luck also go to all my fellow students I enjoyed learning with you all and I hope to see some if not all of your in the next cohort for the Full time course to come. You all have an awesome day. :grinning::hugging_face::raised_hands::clap::v::the_horns::ok_hand::+1:

<!channel> It has been so great getting to spend time with you all over the past eight weeks. I’ve loved watching each of you level up your JavaScript skills. I just wanted to thank you for your patience with me as I’ve figured out this whole teaching thing :slightly_smiling_face:

If there’s ever anything I can do for you, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me. My personal email address is <mailto:jakebrbell@gmail.com|jakebrbell@gmail.com>. Also, feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn: <http://linkedin.com/in/jakebrbell|linkedin.com/in/jakebrbell>. Happy coding!
Have fun working on your final projects and let me know if you run into any roadblocks!

messages.text: Let me know if you run into any issues or roadblocks. Happy coding!
It’s free and it will give you some practice writing out the code. They may not follow all of the conventions we’ve used, but that’s fine.
If you’re still feeling shaky with jQuery, I highly recommend you find ways to practice the syntax. One way to practice is with codecademy’s jQuery course: <https://www.codecademy.com/learn/jquery>

attachments.title: jQuery
attachments.text: Codecademy is the easiest way to learn how to code. It's interactive, fun, and you can do it with your friends.

messages.text: I was able to get the example working so you could toggle the `completed` class on all the todos. The problem was being caused because on the second event handler I was targeting all h2 elements with `$(‘h2’)`. So something about assigning the same element multiple event handlers was breaking it. To solve the problem, I instead attached the event listener only to the newly created h2 by referencing the variable `$h2` instead (see the `index.js` file above).
`index.js`
`index.css`
`index.html`
Also, here is the example we were working on in class:
See above for the solutions for the jQuery assignments.

<!channel> Thank you for coming to class last night! I’m sorry things were rushed and we ran a little over. 

I’ve given everyone access to the three Timers and Events assignments in the HTML, CSS, and JavaScript classroom on <http://repl.it|repl.it>. As I mentioned in class, these assignments are more difficult than the exercises we’ve had lately so don’t get frustrated if you don’t immediately get them working. We will spend more time next Monday working on them in class.
And here is the `index.css` file for the solution to jQuery Exercise 3:

<!channel> Here is the solution to the DOM Exercise 1:
ah, right. Thank you! I was ignoring that part, thinking it was only about suppressing all already-read titles.
So the `displayBook()` function didn’t have to worry about how to get the book from the `bookshelf`. That logic is being handled by the `for` loop, not the function.

<@U35G1S40M> In our example, we defined the function to only take in a single book (object) from the bookshelf (array). Then we invoked the function inside of a loop passing in each book one at a time.

Hi, Jake! things have gotten a little hazier over the weekend... In the bookshelf example from Wednesday, can you remind me of how the function we called displayBook knew to look inside the array called bookshelf to find title, author, pages, bookImg, etc? (Part of my problem may be discerning the difference in the JS code between calling "bookshelf" as a div ID from the HTML and "bookshelf" as the library array. )

<!channel> Just a reminder that the homework due on Monday is the three DOM exercises in the new HTML/CSS <http://repl.it|repl.it> classroom (see invitation above if you haven’t already signed in). 

It would also be a good idea to review Chapter 9 of JS for Kids, especially the sections on jQuery since that is what we’ll be spending most of our time on in class on Monday. 

As always, let me know if you have any questions or if you get stuck on something. Happy coding!

messages.text:
<!channel> Thank you again for a great class last night! If you haven’t already, please go into <http://repl.it|repl.it> and submit your hangman game. I’ve created a JS Hangman Game exercise where you can copy and paste your code and then submit the assignment. 

The homework from last night is explained here: <https://gist.github.com/jakebrbell/4b74a87a114b0f400dfb5e6e8defc9d9>. Let me know if you have any questions about it. 

For Wednesday night’s class, please read Chapter 9 in JS for Kids on The DOM and jQuery. Understanding the DOM can be tricky for beginning programmers, so the more time you spend reviewing the chapter, the easier Wednesday night’s class will be. 

As always, don’t hesitate to send me a message here on Slack if you get stuck on something or have questions. Happy coding!
<@U43MC4933> I’m sorry to hear that! Get lots of rest and feel better soon. I’ll send out a note about the homework after class tonight or tomorrow morning.

I am as sick as a dog and wont be in class tonight. Is there any way someone would be willing to shoot me over any pertinent notes or links or instructions so I can catch myself up. I'd appreciate any help as I dont want to miss class but also dont want to infect everyone with this nasty bug. Hoping I'll be on the mend by Wednesday
As always, let me know if you run into any roadblocks. Happy coding!

Additionally, make sure you read Chapter 5 (HTML) in JS for Kids and download a text editor on your laptop. I don’t care which one you choose, but my recommendation is Atom. You can download it for free here: <https://atom.io/>

attachments.title: A hackable text editor for the 21st Century
attachments.text: At GitHub, we’re building the text editor we’ve always wanted: hackable to the core, but approachable on the first day without ever touching a config file. We can’t wait to see what you build with it.
attachments.fallback: Atom: A hackable text editor for the 21st Century

<!channel> For Monday night’s class we will be continuing to discuss functions. We will start by going over the exercises from this week and then spend most of the time in class working on more exercises. Make sure you complete the function exercises in <http://repl.it|repl.it> before class on Monday. If you get through those and still have time, it wouldn’t hurt to review the chapter on functions in JS for Kids.
In case anyone wants to reference the calculator example from tonight’s class:
<https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals>

attachments.title: Template literals
attachments.text: Template literals are string literals allowing embedded expressions. You can use multi-line strings and string interpolation features with them. They were called "template strings" in prior editions of the ES2015 specification.

messages.text: Here are the solutions to Monday’s exercises: <https://gist.github.com/jakebrbell/341c2233e865376cd49df9b8e0f62f8c>

<!channel> Thank you again for another great class last night! For Wednesday’s class, be sure to finish the exercises we worked on in class yesterday and read chapter 8 in JS for Kids to prepare to discuss functions in JavaScript.

<!channel> I’ve decided to push Functions back to Wednesday this week and use tomorrow night’s class to review and solidify what we’ve already covered. These topics are fundamental to understanding JavaScript so I want to make sure we all feel comfortable with them before moving on. I’ll have some exercises we can work on together to practice with Objects, Arrays, Loops, and Conditionals. We can also go over any of the exercises people are struggling with. The reading assignment for tomorrow night is to review the chapters we’ve already read (especially any you are feeling particularly unsure about).
Are we supposed to read Functions, pages 123 - 139, for Monday?

Here early, if anyone wants to study!

<!channel> Thank you everyone for another great class last night! Here are the things to work on for our class on Wednesday:

1) Read chapter 4 on Objects in JS for Kids (I really mean it this time). We’ll have a quiz on the chapter at the beginning of class on Wednesday. 

2) Complete the Array exercises in <http://repl.it|repl.it>. They are: Array Creation & Access, Strings are like Arrays, and Arrays and Loops. Make sure you’ve completed all the previous exercises as well.

If you finish everything else and want to get a head start on the exercises for Objects, I just made those available in <http://repl.it|repl.it> as well. They are: Creating Objects, Easy Object Access, and Object Access.
Here’s the quiz for chapter 3 (Arrays): <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1YIgV-1BwrlAHSe0-_Ig8dortaBaNjOtdHBUslE8uUSY/>
If you already read through chapter 4, you’ll be extra prepared for Wednesday’s class

<!channel>: Thanks for a great class tonight! As a reminder, here are the things to work on before our next class on *Wednesday, Feb. 22*. 

1. Take the quiz for chapters 1 and 2 of JavaScript for Kids: <https://docs.google.com/a/galvanize.com/forms/d/1kycNce0QINAcDPZ_D6Rv79u2NqFY7Ws0ejtmxFoX3zA>

There are multiple parts so be sure to click next at the bottom of each page. 

2. Finish the assignments in <http://repl.it|repl.it> from this week: Booleans and Comparison, Variables with Numbers, Variables with Undefined or Null, and Variables with Strings. 

3. Do the reading for next week: Chapter 6 of JavaScript for Kids.

4. (Optional) Start working on the assignments in <http://repl.it|repl.it> for next week: Conditionals, While Loops, and For Loops.
